_prev_prog_3.MH_OtherType: Unloading truck hits the unloading pipe

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

October 2020 Resubmission - The purpose of this resubmission is to provide the required 5-year update.  A summary of the updates is provided below:

Section 1

¿	Section 1.7 Update terminal manager and contact information, 
¿	Section 1.8 Update emergency contact information, 
¿	Section 1.9 Add Environmental Engineer (Jim Janson) as corporate contact,
¿	Section 1.14 Last Safety Inspection was performed on 9/1/2020 by local Fire Department, and
¿	Section 1.18 Update Preparer Information (Sierra Piedmont).

Section 2 

Not Used - Does Not Apply.

Section 3

Not Used - Does Not Apply.

Section 4

¿	Section 4.7 - Update residential population at 30 based on 14 houses within 1,400 ft of property and average number of people per house is 2.12 for Norris City  (source: affordablehousingonline.com and google maps).
¿	Section 4.8 - Update public receptors - Remove recreation area.  A map search of the area indicated there are no recreation areas or centers within the endpoint distance.
 
Section 5

¿	Section 5.6 - Recalculated end point of worse-case vapor cloud explosion using RMP*Comp.  Revised from 0.02 miles (106 ft) to 0.05 miles (264 ft).  No change in affected receptors. 

Section 6

Not Used - Does Not Apply.

Section 7

¿	Section 7.3 Update dates,
¿	Section 7.4 Update dates and revised safety plan. (Revised language and added adverse weather conditions),
¿	Sections 7.5 to 7.10 Update dates, and
¿	Sections 7.12 to 7.15 Update dates.



Section 8 

Not Used - Does Not Apply.

Section 9 

¿	Section 9.5 & 9.6 - Update date.

Process Hazard Analysis Updates

¿	Reviewed in September 2020,
¿	No Major changes to PHA, 
¿	Language revised and clarified, 
¿	Routine inspection added under primary line of defense where appropriate, and
¿	Adverse weather condition of lightning strike added.
¿	All training completed by October 2020.

Basic Site Information


The HWRT Terminal - Norris City, LLC (HWRT)

facility, located at 317, County Road 750 North, Norris City, Illinois, is a terminal for the storage and distribution of various fuels.  Petroleum products (i.e., gasoline and diesel) are received by pipeline.  Transport trucks deliver ethanol, biodiesel, and other additives to the facility.  Transport trucks deliver the products to the facility's customers.  

HWRT qualifies as a Program Level 3 for Butane Injection under NAICS 42471 - Petroleum Bulk Stations.  The butane injection  process includes a 30,000-gallon butane storage tank. Butane has been identified by the Environmental Protection Agency as a regulated substance subject to 40 CFR Part 68, which required the preparation of this Risk Management Plan (RMP).  HWRT is also subject to the OSHA process safety management standard and is submitting a program level 3 Risk Management Plan. No other RPM Program chemical substances are in use at or above threshold quantities at this facility. 

The initial construction of the terminal facility was completed in 1960, and it included construction of Tanks NC-01 through NC-04 for petroleum product storage.  HWRT Terminal - Norris City, LLC purchased the terminal from Crown Central Petroleum Corporation in 2004.

The facility is located on Cherry Street, approximately 0.5 mile west of U.S. Highway 1 and 0.25 mile north of Main Street in Norris City.  The immediate vicinity is sparsely populated; however, the closest residence is across the street from the facility's exit gate.  The facility has fuel and additive storage tanks with capacities ranging from 300 to 2,524,116 gallons.  Each of these fuel tanks is provided with adequate secondary containment.  

The butane injection process is fairly simple.  Liquefied butane gas is delivered in tank trucks and pumped into the butane tank.  Butane is stored under pressure at ambient temperatures.  Butane is injected into gasoline by pumping it into the pipeline as the gasoline is being delivered to an HWRT storage t

e annual inspection. 

Five-year Accident History 

This facility has not had a release of butane or other regulated substance as defined in 40 CFR 68.3 and 68.130 or any OSHA highly hazardous chemical as defined in 40 CFR 29.1910(b) in the last 5 years.


Emergency Response Program

The facility emergency response programs include FRP and SPCC Plans.  The FRP includes information regarding emergency response, hazard identification, various discharge scenarios, descriptions of periodic drills and exercises and describes employee training.  The SPCC Plan includes similar information as well as facility inspection forms.  Employees are typically provided with emergency response training, on-the-job training, spill prevention and spill response training and other supplemental training.

The Facility Response Plan contains specific actions to be taken in response to an accidental release of butane, procedures to inform the public about a release, and first aid and toxicity information regarding butane.  All employees working with butane are trained in handling flammable materials and are provided with annual refresher training.  A copy of this plan has been sent to the White County LEPC.  The telephone number for the LEPC is 618-384-4701.
